displayText: Alright? Alright. Thank you for coming to this third meeting of the design group. I think we made some definite progress at the last one and come up with some interesting suggestions for our new remote control. I'll again very quickly just present some notes of that meeting. The the problem with existing remote controls, we felt, was that they're ugly and that people are prepared to pay a premium for something better. They've got lots of buttons on them that people don't use and find difficult to learn. And people lose them. And We thought that for our new remote control that everybody will want to rush out and buy, that we should look at speech recognition rather than rather than buttons, and that if we have any buttons they should be very few of them and only for those functions that are actually identified that people use. That we want to go for a long lasting battery that we guarantee for the life of the product and a shape that will be instantly recognisable, as a trendy remote control, and B as a Real Reaction product. So that when people are happy with that, they will want to buy everything else from us. Okay. And it'll be prominently displayed as part of the advertising literature that it's guaranteed for life. Kay, I'll just be talking about the components design. And Okay, basically I just looked at what exactly do remotes do. Basically they wait for you to press a key or give a voice command and then this is translated into light signals which are then seen by the TV. The materials we're gonna need to look at the two big ones are the integrated circuit chip and the battery and the integrated circuit chip works in conjunction with a diode transistor or resonator, two more resistors and a capacitor and the battery works in conjunction with a resistor and a capacitor. Um. Basically what happens is you'll press a number or give a voice command and this creates a connection within the remote that allows the chip then senses this connection and produces a signal in a Morse code format. This signal's sent to the transistor which amplifies it and then sends it on to the light emitting diode which is then changed into a infrared light which is sent to the TV and sort of seen by the TV and which changes the channels. Um. Oh. Cool. So as for how we should end up using this in our remote couple of main questions are the buttons. We also need to look at the chips, custom-designed versus off the shelf, and the custom-designed will give us much more flexibility and enable us to incorporate the voice function that we all seem to have agreed upon. sentences.displayText: Thank you for coming to this third meeting of the design group.
I think we made some definite progress at the last one and come up with some interesting suggestions for our new remote control.
I'll again very quickly just present some notes of that meeting.
The the problem with existing remote controls, we felt, was that they're ugly and that people are prepared to pay a premium for something better.
They've got lots of buttons on them that people don't use and find difficult to learn.

And We thought that for our new remote control that everybody will want to rush out and buy, that we should look at speech recognition rather than rather than buttons, and that if we have any buttons they should be very few of them and only for those functions that are actually identified that people use.

That we want to go for a long lasting battery that we guarantee for the life of the product and a shape that will be instantly recognisable, as a trendy remote control, and B as a Real Reaction product.
So that when people are happy with that, they will want to buy everything else from us.
So again we'll have the three three presentations from the the three of you and then we'll make a final a final decision.
And the decisions that we need to make today, finally, are what energy source we want to use, whether it is practical to use a a long lasting one.

And I think our discussion was around the fact that if we're gonna go for a long lasting power supply, then basically it's sealed for life and if anybody does manage to run one down, we'll give them another one.
And it'll be prominently displayed as part of the advertising literature that it's guaranteed for life.
Now the the internal chip and this is where I need Kate's expert advice and given that this has to go to market as quickly as possible do we go for a custom designed chip?
Or or do we buy one off the shelf and and programme it ourselves?
I'm I'm not an expert on these things, but presumably, there must be loads of 'em already on the market that we can modify.
But that's that's your area of expertise.
And then the the overall design of the case is is Kendra's field and we had some discussions last time as to how we might go forward and we'll finalise those today.
And this is all linked in with the the user interface, whether we go for voice, buttons, or a bit of both.
And then for the next meeting Kate will be looking at the the the look, feel and design, Kendra how the user actually uses it and Andrew of course the product evaluation.
And Kate and Kendra will be producing a model for us to look at.
So, if we can have the three presentations again please, perhaps you'd like to start.
Kay, I'll just be talking about the components design.
And Okay, basically I just looked at what exactly do remotes do.
Basically they wait for you to press a key or give a voice command and then this is translated into light signals which are then seen by the TV.

The materials we're gonna need to look at the two big ones are the integrated circuit chip and the battery and the integrated circuit chip works in conjunction with a diode transistor or resonator, two more resistors and a capacitor and the battery works in conjunction with a resistor and a capacitor.

Basically what happens is you'll press a number or give a voice command and this creates a connection within the remote that allows the chip then senses this connection and produces a signal in a Morse code format.

This signal's sent to the transistor which amplifies it and then sends it on to the light emitting diode which is then changed into a infrared light which is sent to the TV and sort of seen by the TV and which changes the channels.
So as for how we should end up using this in our remote couple of main questions are the buttons.
The fewer buttons you have, I guess the fewer internal connections and internal codes you're gonna need.
However to not have buttons or to use a voice commands instead of buttons might make these connections more difficult and raise the production cost.
That's something we should think about.
Also we have to work within the company constraints, and the company has informed me via email that they're experts at pushbuttons and that seems to be the most cost-effective way of producing it.

Also with battery connections the company has some limits on the batteries we can use, so I was thinking perhaps a combination of solar cells with a back-up basic battery and somehow between the combination of that two we might be able to come up with something that will last the lifetime or the five to ten years and we could still keep that original idea.

We also need to look at the chips, custom-designed versus off the shelf, and the custom-designed will give us much more flexibility and enable us to incorporate the voice function that we all seem to have agreed upon.

However that's gonna cost more, but off the shelf is gonna be cheaper and it's gonna allow us to produce it quicker and get out there faster, but it's going to be less flexible with the features, especially things like voice activation, which haven't really been used much on remotes, so there's not really chips out there that would be easy to convert, so if we were definitely gonna go with the voice option we'd probably have to design our own chip.
And that pretty much sums it up.
Okay, so how sorry, can you just put that one back up again, please?
Okay, inevitably a custom design chip is gonna be more expensive.
Do we know by how much?
I don't actually have any price information, no.
And do we know how long it'll take to develop a custom chip.
It a lot longer than an off the shelf chip.
The problem is the the voice technology is not really highly developed, it's sort of still still in an experimental form, so it's hard to predict the time.
Right, I think we need to make a decision here.
Given that the company wants this on the market quickly and cheaply, that would appear to effectively constrain us to an existing chip and thus therefore conventional button technology.
